body: Did a first pass, this generally looks good. Something we want to consider is how we want to expose `Exception`s thrown by our components. e.g. if the `RestSharp` client throws an `Exception`, do we want to wrap it as one of our `Exception`s? This was one of the major usability issues in ASA, where our service component calling the client code didn't catch `Exception`s from our underlying components, namely the .NET `HttpClient`.

Our strategy for renaming public methods/fields which are not part of test code or examples is: mark old name as obsolete (with release number for simplicity), create new name alongside, change all occurrences of old name to new one and change old name to call new one. And create a JIRA to remove these obsoleted items, blocked on next release (0.14 in this case), as a reminder. This way, after next release we can safely remove obsolete methods/fields without spending effort on changing their occurrences and without breaking our contract.
I will look at it as well.
Thank you, @tcNickolas . I see. Then, may I create one JIRA per one method like REEF-709/710/711?

I've done a pass.
I really wonder why checkstyle doesn't detect redundant modifiers in these cases. The check for this is http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/config_modifier.html#RedundantModifier and we have it enabled on error-level

Thank you for taking this!

There are only about 26 violations of this check in the code (reef-examples, reef-io, reef-tang and reef-wake modules), and they are trivial to fix. Do you think you could fix them as part of this change, and enable the check on error level? This would save us the overhead of creating extra JIRAs and pull requests to fix the violations and to switch check to error level

One more note: currently we're using two files with checkstyle configuration, identical in everything but severity of JavadocType and TodoComment checks. \lang\java\reef-common\src\main\resources\checkstyle.xml is used for modules which are not yet done as part of REEF-519, \lang\java\reef-common\src\main\resources\checkstyle-strict.xml is used once REEF-519 is fixed for the module. When we add new check, we have to add it in both files, so that we keep them identical.
Thank you, @tcNickolas . I finished updating. Also, I rebased this PR to the master.
It looks good to me and I tested. I'll merge this.
@tcNickolas OK, I'll fix the violations as part of this JIRA.

This check seems to produce false positives with nested generics. For instance, it raises errors with  lines 64 and 135 in [HandlerContainer.java](https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/blob/b9b8dca4aabed02554d631a33e8b1d3be4e04b61/lang/java/reef-wake/wake/src/main/java/org/apache/reef/wake/remote/impl/HandlerContainer.java). Inserting the diamond there causes the "Incompatible types" compilation error. Apparently,  [we do need types](http://stackoverflow.com/a/20548655) in such cases because generics are contravariant.

I suggest we use this check with the warning level.

Warning-level check is not actionable, we can't expect people to look at checkstyle output after every build to see whether any new warnings are added. In the past for checks which are mostly correct but sometimes produce false positives we did the following: make check error-level, but for known false positives configure explicit exceptions using @SuppressWarnings. HiddenField is one example of such check, I think. Probably we should use this approach here as well.
Thanks, @tcNickolas I've addressed your comments.

@gyeongin, you've slightly changed how `RunningTask` and `FailedTask` events are broadcasted (e.g. there's no `commGroupRunningTaskHandler` now). Could you
@gyeongin Could you describe in detail what has changed? Some changes don't seem to be included in the pull request description.

Here is my comments in general:
*The result handler needs to be implemented by client. Client needs to write it in the format in the same way as the input, meaning mirror the deserializer, they should implement serializer. Otherwise downstream will not be able to consume it.
*Interface should be defined in REEF IO rather than IMRU
*Similar to FileSystemPartitionDataSet, FilePartitionDescriptor and FileSystemPartition, we should have similar implementation for output as output data can also be partitioned. 
Have discussed it with Dhruv and Beysim, we need to have a separate Jira to address the issue.
I've done a first pass.
